Sum of angles identity

This Key Point introduces two further important identities.

Key Point

\[\begin{aligned} \sin (A+B) &\equiv \sin A\cos B+\cos A\sin B \qquad \qquad (1) \\ \cos(A+B) &\equiv \cos A\cos B-\sin A\sin B \qquad \qquad (2) \end{aligned}\]

Note carefully the addition sign in \((1)\) but the subtraction sign in \((2)\). Further identities can readily be obtained from \((1)\) and \((2)\).

Dividing \((1)\) by \((2)\) we obtain

\[\tan(A+B)\equiv \dfrac{\sin(A+B)}{\cos(A+B)}\equiv \dfrac{\sin A\cos B+\cos A\sin B}{\cos A\cos B-\sin A\sin B}\]

Dividing every term by \(\cos A\ \cos B\) we obtain:

\[\tan (A+B)\equiv \dfrac{\tan A+\tan B}{1-\tan A\tan B}\]

Replacing \(B\) by \(-B\) in \((1)\) and \((2)\) and remembering that \(\cos (-B)\equiv \cos B\) and \(\sin(-B)\equiv -\sin B\) we find

\[\begin{aligned} \sin(A-B) &\equiv \sin A\cos B-\cos A\sin B \\ \cos (A-B) &\equiv \cos A\cos B+\sin A\sin B. \end{aligned}\]
